channel.title: Comments for The Bavinck Institute
channel.description: Reformed catholic theology in the tradition of Herman and J. H. Bavinck

item.title: Comment on Bavinck Review 7 Published by Daniel Cole
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cole
item.description: Just want to say how much I appreciate the availability of a scholarly EJournal at no cost! I have downloaded all the Journals since Volume 1. The Dutch Reformed tradition is rich and applicable today. I have read so much of Kuyper's works and has been a pleasure reading Bavinck! Thank you again!
item.content:encoded: Just want to say how much I appreciate the availability of a scholarly EJournal at no cost! I have downloaded all the Journals since Volume 1. The Dutch Reformed tradition is rich and applicable today. I have read so much of Kuyper’s works and has been a pleasure reading Bavinck! Thank you again!

item.title: Comment on #wereldzee: George Harinck follows Kuyper to the ancient ocean by Around the Old World Sea with English subtitles - The Bavinck Institute

item.description: […] George Harinck’s eight-part documentary on Abraham Kuyper’s journey into the Mediterranean Islamic world is now available with English […]

item.title: Comment on The Bavinck Review 5 (2014) Released by Laurence O’Donnell
item.dc:creator: Laurence O’Donnell
item.description:
Hi Chad,
Thanks for writing. TBR 5 is open to the public. <a href="/review/tbr-5-2014/" rel="nofollow">Downloads available here</a>. Enjoy!
item.content:encoded:
Hi Chad,

Thanks for writing. TBR 5 is open to the public. Downloads available here. Enjoy!

item.title: Comment on The Bavinck Review 4 (2013) by Steven Woonhyun Yun
item.dc:creator: Steven Woonhyun Yun
item.content:encoded:
I am pastor in Korea.
My Th. M. Thesis is Trinitarian Sanctification by Herman Bavinck(Korean)
I want to see “The Bavinck Reviews”

item.title: Comment on Call for Papers for the 2011 Bavinck Conference by Laurence O'Donnell
item.dc:creator: Laurence O'Donnell
item.description:
Hi Tim,
Sorry for the confusion. North American students are welcome to submit masters- and undergraduate-level papers. (The PhD paper proposal deadline—February 15—has already passed.)
item.content:encoded:
Hi Tim,

Sorry for the confusion. North American students are welcome to submit masters- and undergraduate-level papers. (The PhD paper proposal deadline—February 15—has already passed.)

item.title: Comment on Call for Papers for the 2011 Bavinck Conference by Tim Proudlove
item.dc:creator: Tim Proudlove
item.description: I'm a little unclear. We have a number of posters about this scholarship up at our seminary. However, the poster says "Scholarship competition - call for papers", and then says "Scholarships available to students in seminaries, divinity schools and faculties of theology outside North America". Since our seminary is within North America, this means we cannot apply? Correct?
item.content:encoded: I’m a little unclear. We have a number of posters about this scholarship up at our seminary. However, the poster says “Scholarship competition – call for papers”, and then says “Scholarships available to students in seminaries, divinity schools and faculties of theology outside North America”. Since our seminary is within North America, this means we cannot apply? Correct?
